nodes.label: Geometric Constructions
nodes.title: The process of drawing geometric shapes, angles, and figures accurately using only specific tools such as a compass and straightedge.

nodes.label: Dynamic Geometry Software
nodes.title: Computer programs that allow users to construct and manipulate geometric figures dynamically, aiding in visualization and exploration of geometric concepts.

nodes.label: Precision in Geometric Construction
nodes.title: The use of appropriate instruments and careful techniques to produce accurate geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: Drawing a Circle of Given Radius
nodes.title: The procedure of using a compass to draw a circle with a specified radius.

nodes.label: Use of Straightedge in Construction
nodes.title: Employing a straightedge (without measurement markings) to draw straight lines in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Use of Compass in Construction
nodes.title: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles or to transfer distances in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Use of Ruler in Construction
nodes.title: Utilizing a ruler to measure and draw straight lines of specific lengths in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: Use of Protractor in Construction
nodes.title: Applying a protractor to measure and construct angles accurately in geometric figures.

nodes.label: Use of Set Square in Construction
nodes.title: Using a set square to draw right angles and other specific angles in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: Application of Constructions in Real-life Contexts
nodes.title: Connecting geometric construction techniques to practical, everyday situations and problems.

nodes.label: Cartesian plane
nodes.title: A two-dimensional plane defined by a horizontal axis (x-axis) and a vertical axis (y-axis) used for plotting points, lines, and curves.

nodes.label: Plotting points on the Cartesian plane
nodes.title: The process of locating and marking points using ordered pairs (x, y) on the coordinate plane.

nodes.label: Linear relationship
nodes.title: A relationship between two variables that can be represented by a straight line on a graph and has a constant rate of change.

nodes.label: Tabular representation of linear relationships
nodes.title: Displaying values of variables in a table to show how one variable changes in relation to another in a linear relationship.

nodes.label: Graphical representation of linear relationships
nodes.title: Drawing the graph of a linear relationship on the Cartesian plane to visualize the relationship between variables.

nodes.label: Slope of a line
nodes.title: A measure of the steepness of a line, representing the rate of change between two variables in a linear relationship.

nodes.label: Rate of change
nodes.title: The amount by which one variable changes with respect to another; in linear relationships, it is equivalent to the slope.

nodes.label: Y-intercept (start value)
nodes.title: The value where a linear graph crosses the y-axis, representing the initial value of the dependent variable.

nodes.label: Point of intersection of two lines
nodes.title: The point where two linear graphs cross, representing the solution to a system of two linear equations.

nodes.label: Comparing linear relationships
nodes.title: Analyzing and contrasting different linear relationships by examining their slopes and y-intercepts.

nodes.label: Solving real-life problems with linear relationships
nodes.title: Applying strategies such as graphical, numerical, and mental methods to find solutions to practical problems involving up to two linear relationships.

nodes.label: Right-angled triangle
nodes.title: A triangle in which one of the angles is exactly 90 degrees.

nodes.label: Pythagoras' theorem
nodes.title: A theorem stating that in a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

nodes.label: Application of Pythagoras' theorem to heights and distances
nodes.title: Using Pythagoras' theorem to solve real-world problems involving the measurement of heights and distances in right-angled triangles.

nodes.label: Trigonometric ratios
nodes.title: Ratios of the lengths of sides in a right-angled triangle, specifically sine, cosine, and tangent.

nodes.label: Solving real-world problems using trigonometric ratios
nodes.title: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to determine unknown sides or angles in practical situations involving right-angled triangles.

nodes.label: translation
nodes.title: A transformation that moves every point of a shape the same distance in the same direction.

nodes.label: central symmetry
nodes.title: A transformation where each point and its image are on opposite sides of a central point and at equal distances from it.

nodes.label: axial symmetry
nodes.title: A symmetry with respect to a line (axis), where each point and its image are equidistant from the axis on opposite sides.

nodes.label: rotation
nodes.title: A transformation that turns a shape around a fixed point by a certain angle.

nodes.label: enlargement
nodes.title: A transformation that changes the size of a shape by a scale factor from a fixed center, preserving shape but not necessarily size.

nodes.label: centre of enlargement
nodes.title: The fixed point from which all points are enlarged or reduced in an enlargement transformation.

nodes.label: scale factor
nodes.title: A number which scales, or multiplies, the dimensions of a shape in an enlargement; determines the degree of enlargement or reduction.

nodes.label: effect of enlargement on area
nodes.title: The area of an enlarged shape changes by the square of the scale factor compared to the original.

nodes.label: axis of symmetry
nodes.title: A line that divides a shape into two identical parts that are mirror images of each other.

nodes.label: recognition of images under transformations
nodes.title: The ability to identify the result of applying a transformation (such as translation, symmetry, or rotation) to a shape or point.

nodes.label: solving problems involving enlargements
nodes.title: Applying knowledge of enlargements, scale factors, and centers to solve geometric problems.

nodes.label: synthetic geometry
nodes.title: A branch of geometry that relies on axioms, theorems, and logical reasoning rather than coordinates or algebraic methods.

nodes.label: geometric construction
nodes.title: The process of drawing geometric shapes, angles, and lines accurately using only a compass and straightedge.

nodes.label: construction 16-21
nodes.title: Specific geometric constructions as outlined in the referenced curriculum, typically involving constructing particular shapes or figures.

nodes.label: construction 22
nodes.title: A particular geometric construction task as specified in the curriculum, requiring compass and straightedge techniques.

nodes.label: theorem
nodes.title: A mathematical statement that has been proven to be true based on axioms and logical reasoning.

nodes.label: proof
nodes.title: A logical argument demonstrating the truth of a mathematical statement using axioms, definitions, and previously established theorems.

nodes.label: axiom
nodes.title: A basic assumption or self-evident truth used as a starting point for further reasoning and theorems in mathematics.

nodes.label: corollary
nodes.title: A proposition that follows with little or no proof required from an already proven statement.

nodes.label: converse
nodes.title: A statement formed by reversing the hypothesis and conclusion of a given conditional statement.

nodes.label: implies
nodes.title: A logical relationship where the truth of one statement guarantees the truth of another.

nodes.label: is equivalent to
nodes.title: A logical relationship indicating that two statements are both true or both false under the same conditions.

nodes.label: if and only if
nodes.title: A logical connector indicating that two statements are true simultaneously; each implies the other.

nodes.label: proof by contradiction
nodes.title: A method of proving a statement by assuming the opposite is true and showing this leads to a contradiction.

nodes.label: theorem 7
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 8
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 11
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem concerning ratios, foundational for the proof of the Pythagorean theorem.

nodes.label: theorem 12
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem concerning ratios, foundational for the proof of the Pythagorean theorem.

nodes.label: theorem 13
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem concerning ratios, foundational for the proof of the Pythagorean theorem.

nodes.label: theorem 16
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 17
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 18
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 20
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: theorem 21
nodes.title: A specific geometric theorem referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: corollary 6
nodes.title: A specific corollary referenced in the curriculum, details found in the source text.

nodes.label: ratios in geometry
nodes.title: The comparison of two quantities in geometry, often used in similar triangles and proportional reasoning.

nodes.label: theorem of Pythagoras
nodes.title: A fundamental theorem in geometry stating that in a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

nodes.label: Parallel Lines
nodes.title: Two lines in a plane that never intersect and have the same slope.

nodes.label: Perpendicular Lines
nodes.title: Two lines that intersect at a right angle (90 degrees), with slopes that are negative reciprocals of each other.

nodes.label: Linear Equation in Two Variables
nodes.title: An equation of the form ax + by + c = 0, representing a straight line in the Cartesian plane.

nodes.label: Area of a Triangle (Coordinate Geometry)
nodes.title: The calculation of the area of a triangle given the coordinates of its vertices, often using the determinant formula.

nodes.label: Equation of a Circle (Standard Form)
nodes.title: The equation (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2 represents all points (x, y) at a distance r from the center (h, k).

nodes.label: Equation of a Circle (General Form)
nodes.title: The equation x^2 + y^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 represents a circle with center (-g, -f) and radius r = sqrt(g^2 + f^2 - c).

nodes.label: Perpendicular Distance from a Point to a Line
nodes.title: The shortest distance from a given point to a specified straight line in the plane.

nodes.label: Angle Between Two Lines
nodes.title: The measure of the angle formed at the intersection of two lines, calculated using their slopes.

nodes.label: Internal Division of a Line Segment
nodes.title: Dividing a line segment into a given ratio m:n internally, finding the coordinates of the dividing point.

nodes.label: Intersection of a Line and a Circle
nodes.title: Solving for the points where a line and a circle meet in the coordinate plane.

nodes.label: Relationship Between Line and Circle (Origin Center)
nodes.title: Solving problems involving a line and a circle centered at the origin (0, 0).

nodes.label: Pythagoras' Theorem in 2D
nodes.title: Using the Pythagorean theorem to solve problems involving right-angled triangles in two dimensions.

nodes.label: Trigonometric Area of a Triangle
nodes.title: Calculating the area of a triangle using trigonometric formulas, such as 1/2 ab sin C.

nodes.label: Sine Rule (Law of Sines)
nodes.title: Using the sine rule to solve for unknown sides or angles in non-right triangles.

nodes.label: Cosine Rule (Law of Cosines)
nodes.title: Using the cosine rule to solve for unknown sides or angles in triangles.

nodes.label: Definition of Sine and Cosine for All Angles
nodes.title: Defining sin θ and cos θ for all values of θ, including negative and angles greater than 360°.

nodes.label: Definition of Tangent
nodes.title: Defining tan θ as the ratio of sine to cosine for all valid values of θ.

nodes.label: Area of a Sector of a Circle
nodes.title: Calculating the area of a sector using the central angle and radius.

nodes.label: Length of an Arc
nodes.title: Finding the length of an arc of a circle given the radius and central angle.

nodes.label: Trigonometric Ratios in Surd Form
nodes.title: Working with exact values of trigonometric ratios expressed in surd (root) form.

nodes.label: 3D Trigonometric Problem Solving
nodes.title: Applying trigonometric methods to solve problems in three-dimensional contexts.

nodes.label: Graphing Sine, Cosine, and Tangent Functions
nodes.title: Plotting the graphs of the basic trigonometric functions over a range of angles.

nodes.label: Graphing Transformed Trigonometric Functions
nodes.title: Graphing functions of the form f(θ) = a + b sin cθ and g(θ) = a + b cos cθ for real values of a, b, c.

nodes.label: Solving Trigonometric Equations
nodes.title: Solving equations such as sin nθ = 0 and cos nθ = 1/2 and giving all possible solutions.

nodes.label: Radian Measure of Angles
nodes.title: Using radians as a unit for measuring angles instead of degrees.

nodes.label: Derivation of Trigonometric Formulae
nodes.title: Deriving key trigonometric identities and formulas as specified in the curriculum.

nodes.label: Application of Trigonometric Formulae
nodes.title: Applying a range of trigonometric formulas (as specified in the curriculum) to solve problems.

nodes.label: enlargement (transformation geometry)
nodes.title: A transformation that produces an image that is the same shape as the original, but a different size, using a centre of enlargement and a scale factor.

nodes.label: scale factor (enlargement)
nodes.title: A number k that determines how much the figure is enlarged or reduced in an enlargement transformation; k > 1 for enlargements, 0 < k < 1 for reductions.

nodes.label: rational scale factor
nodes.title: A scale factor k for enlargement where k is a rational number (k ∈ Q).

nodes.label: problem solving with enlargements
nodes.title: Applying knowledge of enlargement transformations to solve geometric problems, including determining images, pre-images, and effects on area.
